text: He will bless them that fear the LORD, both small and great.
text_kjv: He will bless them that fear the LORD, both small and great.
text_niv: he will bless those who fear the Lord—small and great alike.
text_esv: he will bless those who fear the LORD, both the small and the great.
text_nlt: He will bless those who fear the LORD,both great and lowly.
text_msg: And let God bless all who fear God—bless the small, bless the great.
text_nasb: He will bless those who fear the LORD, The small together with the great.
context: Psalm 115, likely composed after the Babylonian exile, contrasts the impotence of idols with the power and sovereignty of Yahweh, the God of Israel. The psalm served as a liturgical hymn, perhaps sung antiphonally by priests and the congregation, to reaffirm faith in God's steadfast love and protection in the face of national rebuilding and the constant temptation to adopt foreign deities. The 'small and great' represent the entire community, regardless of social standing or influence, emphasizing the universality of God's blessing to those who revere Him. The restoration period was marked by both hope and hardship; the Jewish people had returned to a ruined Jerusalem and were tasked with rebuilding their temple and society under Persian rule. This verse would have served as a powerful reminder that despite their vulnerable circumstances, God's blessing was available to all who remained faithful. The emphasis on fearing the Lord wasn't just about terror; it encapsulated reverence, obedience, and trust, reflecting a covenant relationship that promised protection and prosperity. Understanding this historical context emphasizes the encouragement this verse would have provided to a struggling community clinging to their faith during a period of uncertainty and reconstruction. The psalm itself stands as a testament to the enduring power of faith in a God who actively intervenes in the lives of His people.
meaning: Psalm 115:13's theological meaning lies in its emphasis on God's impartial blessing to all who fear Him, regardless of social status. The phrase 'fear the LORD' encapsulates more than mere terror; it denotes a profound respect, reverence, and obedience stemming from a deep understanding of God's power, holiness, and covenantal relationship with His people. This fear is not crippling but rather a motivating force towards righteousness and faithfulness. God's blessing, in this context, encompasses a wide range of benefits: physical provision, protection from enemies, spiritual growth, and a flourishing community life. The words 'small and great' underscore the universality of God's grace; He does not discriminate based on wealth, power, or social standing. Every individual who honors and obeys Him can expect to receive His blessings. This contrasts sharply with pagan religions where blessings were often seen as the exclusive domain of the elite or dependent on elaborate rituals and sacrifices. Psalm 115 reiterates that access to God's favor is not based on human merit or position but solely on one's heart attitude towards Him. The verse speaks of God's active involvement in the lives of those who fear Him, not as a passive observer but as a loving and attentive Father who desires to bless His children. It underscores the importance of cultivating a relationship with God characterized by reverence, obedience, and trust, for it is through this relationship that we access His abundant blessings.
application: In modern application, Psalm 115:13 serves as a powerful reminder that God's blessings are available to all believers, irrespective of their background or social standing. It challenges us to cultivate a 'fear of the LORD' that is more than just lip service but a heartfelt reverence that shapes our thoughts, words, and actions. Practically, this means striving to live a life that is pleasing to God, obeying His commandments, and seeking His will in all we do. In a world often driven by ambition, status, and material wealth, this verse calls us to prioritize our relationship with God above all else, trusting that He will provide for our needs and bless our efforts. We should actively seek to understand God's character and attributes, meditating on His Word and engaging in prayer, so that our 'fear' is rooted in a deep knowledge and appreciation of who He is. The verse also reminds us to treat everyone with respect and dignity, recognizing that all are created in God's image and are potential recipients of His blessing. We should extend kindness and compassion to those less fortunate, remembering that God's love embraces both the 'small and great.' Furthermore, we can apply this verse by fostering a culture of reverence within our families, churches, and communities, teaching our children to honor God and encouraging one another to live lives of obedience and faith. Finally, in times of hardship or uncertainty, this verse can serve as a source of comfort and encouragement, reminding us that God is still in control and that His blessings are available to all who trust in Him. Living out Psalm 115:13 requires a conscious decision to prioritize God in all aspects of our lives and to extend His love and grace to others.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for your promise to bless those who fear you, both small and great. I confess that at times, my reverence for you wavers amidst the distractions and pressures of this world. Help me to cultivate a deeper, more genuine fear of you – a fear rooted in love, respect, and obedience. Lord, show me the areas of my life where I am not fully honoring you, and give me the strength to turn away from sin and embrace righteousness. Pour out your blessings upon me, not according to my merit, but according to your grace and mercy. Bless my family, my church, and my community. May we all strive to live lives that are pleasing in your sight. Thank you for your unwavering love and your promise to never leave or forsake those who trust in you. In Jesus' name, I pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: To 'fear the LORD' isn't just being scared of God. It's a deep reverence, respect, and awe towards His power, holiness, and character. It includes obedience to His commands and a desire to live a life that pleases Him, acknowledging His authority in all things.
faqs.question: What does it mean to 'fear the LORD'?

faqs.answer: The beauty of this verse is its universality. God's blessing isn't limited to the wealthy or powerful. It extends to everyone who fears Him, regardless of their social standing or economic status. He values humility and faithfulness above all else.
faqs.question: How does this verse apply to people of different social classes?

faqs.answer: God's blessings are multifaceted. They can include physical provision, protection, peace of mind, spiritual growth, and a fulfilling life. Ultimately, the greatest blessing is a close relationship with Him and the promise of eternal life.
faqs.question: What kind of blessings does God promise to those who fear Him?

faqs.answer: The fear of the Lord should never paralyze us with terror. True fear is mixed with love, trust, and gratitude. It motivates us to obey and serve God, not to withdraw from Him in dread. Balance is key.
faqs.question: Is it possible to 'fear the LORD' too much, becoming paralyzed by fear?

faqs.answer: Start by spending time in prayer and studying God's Word. Meditate on His attributes, His holiness, and His love. Seek to obey His commands and to live a life that is pleasing to Him. Surround yourself with other believers who can encourage you in your faith.
faqs.question: How can I cultivate a greater fear of the LORD in my daily life?
